entry.title: Getting your environment ready
entry.summary: Getting the local enviroment ready on your computer
entry.content:
Once you have set up Ubuntu in VirtualBox, the next steps are to install Python, a text editor and any other personal software that you may require for your learning. To begin with, Python and a text editor should suffice.

There are tons of text editors out there, and one could get easily confused with the choices available. I reached out to some of my colleagues for recommendations; Sublime Text & Visual Studio Code seemed to be the general recommendations for beginners. Note that for Windows, you can download the .exe installation files, however, for Ubuntu, you can install them directly via the terminal using sudo commands. You can simply search on Google and you’d be able to find tons of instructions out there on how to do this.

For Python, Ubuntu already comes with a version of Python installed, however, it is best to have the latest one installed. I’d recommend installing it in a Virtual Environment within your working folders. I’ll come to that a bit later, once we’ve started working on some code. Cheers!

entry.title: Setting up your environment
entry.summary: Setting up the local enviroment on your computer
entry.content:
I have a Windows 10 PC with 16GB of RAM and a 500GB SSD Hard Disk. I was keen to initally try setting up my environment in Windows, however, I faced a number of errors just trying to get Python installed.

While it is not impossible to get your environment set up on Windows, as a beginner, I decided to go with a VirtualBox setup and installed Ubuntu in it. My PC has enough processing power, and it was proving to be a significant overhead to try and get Python installed; I thought it was better to go with an Ubuntu setup as I also found instructions on the web much easier to follow for Ubuntu.

I installed VirtualBox and gave it about half of my RAM (around 8GB), and about 100 GB of hard drive space. While 2GB should be enough for the RAM, I decided to give it more power as I anticipate running heavy queries in the future. And with that, we’re good to kick off our learning!
